text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

NARRATOR: In our
knowledge-based world,

the health of a
nation's economy depends

on a workforce that is
well-educated in science,

technology, engineering,
and mathematics.

There is increasing concern
that the United States is
falling behind other countries.

MIT has historically
made significant efforts

to help high school educators
improve science and technology
instruction.

MIT OpenCourseWare
continues this tradition

through Highlights for High
School, a website specifically

designed for secondary
education students and teachers.

THOMAS MAGNANTI: The concept
of this OpenCourseWare

for high schools came as the
confluence of, I would say,
three themes.
One is a national need.

And it's been well-documented
in "The Gathering Storm"

and various other
reports that we

need to invest more in secondary
education, K through 12

education, particularly in STEM
fields-- science, technology,
engineering, and mathematics.

The second is MIT, as a
leading institution of science

and technology,
has an obligation
to contribute to education.

And third would be for us to
do something that scalable
and has a large impact.

And here we have a
platform for doing that.

NARRATOR: A portal into
MIT's OpenCourseWare content,

Highlights for High
School provides

easy access to the introductory
level courses on OCW.

Maps thousands of individual
learning resources

from the OCW site to the
advanced placement curriculum.

And presents
resources to inspire

the study of science,
technology, math,
and engineering.

Highlights for High School
provides accessible lists

of introductory courses
from the MIT curriculum.

This format provides extended
descriptions and guidance,

helping students develop
confidence in their ability
to study at the college level.

GUEST SPEAKER: I first
visited MIT OCW merely

to consider options
for a college major.

But soon realized the true
depth of the material.

Many intro level
classes on OCW are

extremely relevant to
an advanced high school
curriculum.

NARRATOR: Highlights also maps
more than 2,600 OCW learning

resources to the AP
physics, biology,

and calculus curriculum, a
structure already familiar

to high school
students and educators.

Through these maps,
students and educators

can easily access videos,
demonstrations, and assignments

that illustrate specific topics
addressed in the AP framework.
GUEST SPEAKER: I feel elated.

I want to teach my honors
students as a pre-AP bio

class with the site
this year using the OCW

resources to get them familiar
with advanced placement themes.

NARRATOR: Highlights for
High School materials

invite students to discover
how they can use science, math,

and technology to
make a difference
in their lives and their world.

The portal also
presents the best

of OCW's hands-on materials,
including labs, demonstrations,

and competitions, all designed
to engage high school students

and to demonstrate that
learning science, math,

and technology subjects can
be exciting and creative.

GUEST SPEAKER: MIT
affords students

an in-depth perspective
into MIT scholarship.
And it's inspiring.

It inspires them
because it lets them

know that they can
understand and appreciate

these difficult concepts on
the level of MIT students.

THOMAS MAGNANTI: And so
our big idea, in some ways,

is to inspire, to
inspire students

to learn more engineering,
learn more mathematics,

learn more basic science
and be able to apply it.

The second aspect
of this is just

to improve and enrich
the current education

in science and mathematics in
the secondary education system.

NARRATOR: Highlights for High
School, unlocking knowledge,
inspiring young minds.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
